answers.answer: Hello,Some of the important causes of leg cramps are overextension of the muscles,overweight, dehydration, alterations in the balance of salts in the bloodstream (such as a high or low sodium,calcium or potassium level),neuropathy(esp in diabetes),hypothyroidism,peripheral vascular disease(narrowing of the arteries which causes poor circulation),sarcoidosis, nerve compression, and sometimes liver disease.Some of these causes like dehydration,being overweight,alcohol intake are modifiable by efforts of the patient. Stretching and massaging the affected muscle (usually a calf muscle) can usually relieve an attack of cramp. A painkiller such as paracetamol may help to ease muscle discomfort and tenderness that sometimes persists for up to 24 hours after a cramp has gone.My advise is to consult a physician and rule out the above medical conditions by thorough investigations as without physical examination and investigations, pinpointing a diagnosis is tough.Hope it helps.Take care and pls do keep me posted on how you are doing or if you have any additional queries.Kind regards.

question: I am 22 years old and have  done regular cardio exercises since I was 6 years old when I started doing karate type trainining.  I added weight training around age 12 or so.  I continue to do cardio and weight training 4-6 times a week.  I have always cramped easily after exercise.  Several times I have cramped to the point of having to go to the hospital to be given medical treatment.  I am finding that I can no longer go through an entire exercise regime without cramping excessively.  I do not use drugs or medications of any kind.  I drink about a gallon of water or more each day.  I try to eat correctly.  I only use alcohol occasionally.  I am not even able to participate in team sports such as a regular male soft ball game without ending the game in cramps.  These cramps are over all of my body.  Any ideas?
title: Muscle cramps over entire body
